causes: Rising nationalist movements in the Balkans (e.g., in Romania, Serbia, Bulgaria)
Russian desire to expand influence in the Balkans and weaken Ottoman control
Russian protection of Slavic and Christian populations under Ottoman rule
events_leading_up_to_war: Serbia and Romania declare war on the Ottoman Empire with Russian support
Russian army crosses the Danube River into Ottoman-controlled territories
Turkey's attempt to suppress nationalist uprisings in Bulgaria, leading to civilian massacres (April 1876), which causes international outrage

result.territorial_changes: Russia gains control of parts of the Caucasus and the Danube Delta, and significant influence in the Balkans, especially Bulgaria

major_battles.name: Battle of Shipka Pass
major_battles.description: A decisive battle where Russian forces, alongside Bulgarian volunteers, held off a larger Ottoman force in a series of intense mountain engagements.

major_battles.name: Battle of Plevna
major_battles.description: A prolonged siege where Russian and Romanian forces encircled Ottoman forces in the town of Plevna, leading to the eventual surrender of the Ottoman garrison.

major_battles.name: Siege of Kars
major_battles.description: A successful Russian siege of the Ottoman fortress of Kars, which eventually led to the Ottoman retreat from the region.

terms: Ottoman Empire cedes significant territories to Russia and Bulgaria
Bulgaria is established as a quasi-independent state, significantly enlarged
Autonomy granted to Bosnia and Herzegovina
Ottoman Empire loses territories in the Caucasus
impact: Shift of power in the Balkans towards Russia and away from the Ottoman Empire
Growing nationalism among Slavic populations in the Balkans
Increase in Russian influence over the Balkans, particularly in Bulgaria

long_term_effects: Increased instability in the Balkans, leading to future conflicts
The weakening of the Ottoman Empire and its eventual disintegration
Emergence of the Balkan League, which would contribute to future wars like the Balkan Wars (1912–1913)

economic: Russia gains new territories with valuable resources
Further weakening of the Ottoman economic position in the region
political: Russia solidifies its role as a great power in European geopolitics
The Ottoman Empire's decline accelerates, opening the door for European intervention in the region
social: Bulgaria’s rise as a national entity influences later nationalist movements in the Balkans
Strengthened Russian influence among the Slavic populations of the Balkans
